November 26, 2000: Fiction
WINTER'S HEART, by Robert Jordan. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) The ninth
volume in the fantasy series "The Wheel of Time."
JOURNEY, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) A television anchorwoman in
Washington begins to question her marriage to a powerful man.
THE LAST PRECINCT, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) Kay Scarpetta,
the chief medical examiner for Virginia, comes under suspicion of murder.
THE PROMETHEUS DECEPTION, by Robert Ludlum. (St. Martin's, $27.95.) The
C.I.A. recruits a former deep-cover operative to infiltrate a secret intelligence
group known as the Directorate.
DECK THE HALLS, by Mary Higgins Clark and Carol Higgins Clark. (Scribner/
Simon & Schuster, $18.) A private eye's father is kidnapped before Christmas.
WISH YOU WELL, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $24.95.) In 1940, a 12-year-old
girl living in New York City is forced to move to rural Virginia.
MERRICK, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $26.95.) An almost-mortal vampire recounts the
story of a descendant of the Mayfair Witches.
PRODIGAL SUMMER, by Barbara Kingsolver. (HarperCollins, $26.) The lives of
men and women, flora and fauna, in the mountains of Appalachia.
THE BEAR AND THE DRAGON, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $28.95.) Aided by the
antiterrorism specialist John Clark, President Jack Ryan contends with sinister
forces afoot in Russia and China.
DROWNING RUTH, by Christina Schwarz. (Doubleday, $23.95.) In 1919, after the
mysterious death of her sister, a Wisconsin woman takes control of the family farm
and her niece.
SHOPGIRL, by Steve Martin. (Hyperion, $17.95.) A young California woman
captures the attention of an older millionaire from Seattle.
THE RESCUE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $22.95.) A fireman helps a single
mother search for her missing son, a 4-year-old with severe learning disabilities.
A STORM OF SWORDS, by George R. R. Martin. (Spectra/Bantam, $26.95.) The
third volume of the "Song of Ice and Fire" fantasy saga.
THE CAROUSEL, by Richard Paul Evans. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The love
between a man and a woman is tested by the demands of family and work.
L.A. DEAD, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $24.95.) The lawyer and investigator
Stone Barrington is caught up in Hollywood shenanigans and a murder case.
November 26, 2000
Non-Fiction
THE O'REILLY FACTOR, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $23.) The host of a cable
news program offers opinions on what's right and wrong with America.
THE BEATLES ANTHOLOGY, by The Beatles. (Chronicle, $60.) A profusely
illustrated volume in which John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and
Ringo Starr tell their own story.
JOE DIMAGGIO: The Hero's Life, by Richard Ben Cramer. (Simon & Schuster,
$28.) From San Francisco to the South Bronx: a biography of the Yankee Clipper.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author, a
sportswriter, tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near
death's door.
NOTHING LIKE IT IN THE WORLD, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster,
$28.) The story of the men who built the transcontinental railroad in the 1860's.
ON WRITING, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $25.) The novelist looks back on his
career and offers guidance for would-be authors.
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam,
$24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of
one of them.
AMERICA'S QUEEN, by Sarah Bradford. (Viking, $29.95.) A biography of
Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis (1929-94).
PARIS TO THE MOON, by Adam Gopnik. (Random House, $24.95.) Essays
about France by a former Paris correspondent for The New Yorker.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of people who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
COMMUNION WITH GOD, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam, $23.95.) The
author discusses moments of "open contact with the Divine."
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam,
$24.95.) A memoir by the two-time Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
THE DARWIN AWARDS, by Wendy Northcutt. (Dutton, $16.95.) Commemorating
those people whose spectacularly stupid behavior served to "improve our gene
pool" by removing them from it.
MY FATHER'S DAUGHTER, by Tina Sinatra with Jeff Coplon. (Simon & Schuster,
$26.) A memoir of Frank Sinatra by his younger daughter.
THE UNEXPECTED LEGACY OF DIVORCE, by Judith Wallerstein, Julia Lewis
